comment.author: 54968992@N03
comment._content:
I hate to be pedantic but The Harcourt Station was NOT & is NOT in Rathmines.
It is city centre of Dublin. The description is (totally) inaccurate I'm afraid!
There is NO mention of Rathmines in your tags, so I think it's safe to deduce that Harcourt Street /Hatch Street is NOT  in Rathmines!

comment.author: 54968992@N03
comment._content: Who is responsible for the administration of the Photos uploaded on to FLICKR  as in names, not a department on behalf of the 'National Archives' please???

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/photoken04] You're not being pedantic, you're perfectly correct! Have you never noticed that Flickr Maps leave a lot to be desired about locations, e.g. when I place photos on the National Library in Kildare Street, it insists on saying Ballsbridge, I think, even though that's a good mile away from Kildare Street...
I've now changed Rathmines to the broader "Dublin". Sorry if "Rathmines" was disorienting...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/photoken04] My name is Carol. I manage the account, upload photos, etc. And we're not the National Archives of Ireland - this photostream is the National Library of Ireland on the Commons.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 38896199@N06
comment._content: I believe ClickKen04 likes using upper case... WHATEVER FLOATS YOUR BOAT! In relation to the image (which is what Flickr is all about) i love the way the very same font is still evident in many signs throughout our country today, it is so familiar to me. It is a fine image and a shame this station is no longer! You do a great job Carol, here's to 2012! Looking forward to more of the outstanding images you have uploaded for our perusal!

comment._content: Keep up the great work in 2012, Carol.  I always look forward to seeing what rarities you add each day.

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Carol, I hate to be you know what but you've mistaken an old form Gaelic G for an S - the sign actually reads Maigistir!  You're probably too young to realise that there was an old form script with a number of letters different and distinctive including the G and the T!

comment.author: 54968992@N03
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] 
And you. Btw, I think you are right about the G & S, I seem to remember that 'G' on the old 'Offigh an Phoist' (excuse my Irish spelling), but it seems your observation is indeed pertinent re the  (singular) letter! 
I may be wrong but I seem to remember what you refer to on some Government Vans or trucks in the 60's????

comment.author: 24101413@N03
comment._content: Swordscookie, it can't be made out in the photo but I think it would be "g" with a dot or  "séimhiú", such that the fully-written version would be "máighistir".  As you say, this was the style before the official written language was simplified (sometime in the 1950s?).

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: I'm going to sound or read like an old schoolmaster or somebody who knows what he's talking about but Irish251 the "dot" was known as a "buailte"(? spelling) and the accent was known as a "fada" or "séimhiú".  I had the unpleasant experience of learning to write Irish in the old script and when I finished at Primary school they changed it and in my short time at second level I had to learn a whole new way of doing things!

comment.author: 38896199@N06
comment._content: Its lucky you lot are online, otherwise you'd be sitting around with a pipe and slippers talking about the old days! ; )

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Absolutely take your point about the old G, but before I commented, I had checked in my trusty Tomás de Bhaldraithe dictionaries (yes, I'm that nerdy!) and there was no trace of anything like máighistir. All forms of master, including station master are given as máistir only. When back in Library Towers, I'll have to forage through older dictionaries... And [http://www.flickr.com/photos/int0lerant] it's "dúidín agus slipéir"! :D See the dúidín being smoked or at least clenched in mouth in our recent photo from the Giant's Causeway...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 24101413@N03
comment._content: I'm happy to be corrected.  I'm too young to have experienced the "old Irish" at first hand!

comment.author: 73371644@N04
comment._content: I learned the old Irish in the school which stood beside this railway line; now "Windy Arbour" Luas stop. I used to stand on the iron foot-bridge and watch the trains. Before the Luas line opened, I climbed a wall and onto the bridge one last time. I think I might have been the last person to do so before it was removed!

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content:
I went to Farrenboley school, too!

That was 10 years after the Harcourt Street line closed, though.

comment.author: 78026231@N03
comment._content: I was somewhere on that train that day

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/78026231@N03] It sounds as if there was a great atmosphere of excitement on the day! How old were you then (if that's not an impertinent question)?

comment.author: 73371644@N04

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: We are all well, mysterious stranger!

comment.author: 9618622@N08
comment._content: National Library - I was going to mention something about that but skipped the idea. I did hear that someone whose name was known to me was in trouble regarding a light fixture. We had very strict parents and would not dare be involved in that kind of carry-on.  We couldn't wait to get off the train and get to the pub !!!!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/9618622@N08] Tut, tut! And people give out about the youth of today...

comment.author: 9618622@N08
comment._content: I think I know what you mean ! - but for us, it was glasses of MiWadi orange, on the rocks ! Love the banter, but anyway, your collection of photos is excellent - very interesting and with many memories for me. I shall be going through them all again soon. Enjoy your day !
